metadata.title: AI as Design Material. Seeing the Design Role in Creating… | by Jonathan Follett | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Pencils and sketchbooks, markers and whiteboard, pixels and code — these are the items that we typically associate with being design materials. They are the elements that designers use to explore and…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Season 3, Episode 2 — AI As Design Material

all_paragraphs: by Dirk Knemeyer and Jonathan Follett

Pencils and sketchbooks, markers and whiteboard, pixels and code — these are the items that we typically associate with being design materials. They are the elements that designers use to explore and ultimately manifest solutions to the problems they’re called upon to solve. Whether analog or digital, traditional or modern, their form and role in the continuum of design is obvious. Less obvious is the idea that AI, and more specifically machine learning, is also a design material. While we see the impacts of AI on various digital artifacts that impact designers, ranging from the increasing power of common design tools like the Adobe Creative Cloud to emerging platforms like mixed realities, AI itself is usually thought of as a material for software engineers. More, the recent evolution of machine learning is still in the discovery phase of new capabilities and inventions. We’re a long way away from standardized libraries and plug-ins that can be applied by designers in ways similar to the fonts, photos, and icons are today.

Josh Clark is the founder and principal at Big Medium, a New York design studio specializing in future-friendly interfaces for artificial intelligence, connected devices, and responsive Web sites. Clark has spoken and published around the world on his notion that designers should view AI as their newest design material. AI in general, and machine learning in particular, offer a compelling array of features and opportunities for designers to innovate and improve their designed experiences in important ways. While Clark’s thesis that AI is a new material for design is compelling, his idea that it is an available design material now, today, is a counter-intuitive claim — which makes it all the more interesting.

“All designers work with some sort of a material. HTML and CSS are design materials, … data and the visualization of it is a design material,” says Clark. “And, as with all those things, every material has certain strengths and weaknesses. In the same way that I think of a machinist or a woodworker working with the physical material and learning what it can do, what its boundaries are, I think that it’s useful to think about the same thing with machine learning.”

The metaphor of machine learning as a new design material is a smart one. It helps to demystify AI, and also to frame it as something that is in our general purview of use. It’s not just something for big companies and wizard engineers to tame as part of an elaborate show. It is something that can practically impact many different experiences. Designers, whose core expertise is, or at least should be, creating for the benefit of the user experience, thus have remarkable potential to get to know machine learning technologies, understand their contexts of use, and lead the creation of products, services, and experiences that make our lives better in meaningful ways. More than merely connecting us to the technology, designers can now shape technology that makes our lives better. It’s an exciting opportunity.

“For a lot of designers there’s been an assumption that machine learning and artificial intelligence is the domain of data scientists or algorithm engineers, that there may not even be a role for designers,” says Clark. “It’s becoming more clear to me, the more that I work with products that are powered by machine learning, that there’s a huge role for designers, and it very much is a design material that we urgently need some designerly attention given to.”

Clark details five ways that designers can use AI in software products — for recommendation, prediction, classification, clustering, and generation. “[AI] is ready to be used in everyday products, sometimes in small ways,” says Clark. “I think that as machine learning becomes more and more prevalent, as we’re already starting to see happen, and as more and more designers and developers realize that this is a tool that you can have in your kit, it will be as common to sprinkle a little machine learning, a little intelligence into an interface as it is to sprinkle a little JavaScript, a little interaction into a webpage.”

Clark’s perspective helps to, not just further demystify AI usage, but also practically contextualize it. To that point, the first three of these ways in which designers can leverage AI — recommendation, prediction and classification — have been considerations in website and software design going back to the early days. AI enhances these functions, but these are not new approaches, rather an important evolution in the way the functions now operate. Whereas designers in the past were creating literal and static forms, now they can offer dynamic interactions which — when skillfully applied — much improve the user experience. Clark provides some examples of AI use for recommendation, prediction, and classification in products today:

“[For example], Slack for teams, for big enterprise organizations, lets you search for people who are experts in something. You can type in something like ‘human resources’ for example, and it would show the people who talk a lot about human resources. It’s more than a brute force text search. It [provides] recommendations around concepts,” says Clark.

“Prediction is based on historical data: ‘Here’s the thing that’s most likely to happen next’. … In Google’s Gmail feature, it will suggest a word or phrase that will come next, just this little bit of intelligence that you can sprinkle into the application to make that better.”

“A third application [of AI] is classification and that’s really where you’re teaching the machines to match an event or an object or a photo, or a phrase to some sort of classification, some category,” says Clark. “One example of this that we see in everyday products is in Google Forms, Google survey tool, which lets you build surveys by typing in questions and choosing an answer. … Years ago Google added a little bit of machine learning to that so that when you type the question, it defaults to what it believes to be the most likely classification of that answer.”
Clark next describes the AI functions of clustering and generation, which have the potential to provide immense power for new software.

“With clustering, you give the machines a whole bunch of information and it begins to define what the categories are. It recognizes ‘here’s baseline’, ‘here’s normal’, and ‘here’s a whole bunch of things that differ from normal in some interesting or like way’,” says Clark. “One example of that is a system called Deep Patient, which took thousands and thousands of medical records and poured over them to find patterns.” Deep Patient was able to predict, about two years earlier than most human doctors, the onset of schizophrenia. “You can use [Deep Patient] to guide human attention,” says Clark. But, it’s not meant to be a substitute for a doctor’s judgment.

“I think one of the interesting things about this though is that we don’t really understand how or why the machines do this clustering. So, in the case of Deep Patient and schizophrenia, you might think, ‘Oh, this is great. This will give us new understanding into how schizophrenia works.’ But it actually doesn’t.” Deep Patient processes all of the patient records, but we don’t actually know how it arrived at that result. “And even the people who created the system don’t understand it,” says Clark. “So, it’s this tricky thing.” We have the information, but we don’t know how it was arrived at.

“I know several curators who are running their museum’s or institute’s art collections through systems like this and letting machines start to cluster and group them,” says Clark “And the machines do it in ways that are not like human curators would do. They don’t match up to the formal schools of art or periods that we think about art more traditionally, but they are still grouped in interesting ways. At the Barnes Foundation in Philadelphia, when they ran their collection through an image recognition search and started to find, for example, artworks that map to the notion of an angel. It found things that definitely were not angels, including sculpture and vases and sort of some odd things like that, but also things that were also not exactly an angel.”

“You might think, ‘Well, that’s not very useful’. … But, the curators actually looked at it as something that was productive friction, that the machines are strange and they see the world in different ways. They don’t categorize things the way that we necessarily would as human beings. But, that also lets us see the world in new ways that we wouldn’t otherwise be able to see,” says Clark. Productive friction is a useful term: AI can approach problems from a novel perspective, and, while some of the results may not be useful, there can also be ingenious and unexpected discoveries.

Machines can also begin to generate content on our behalf. For instance, FaceApp, a mobile photo editing application, can, among other things, take your picture and, using neural networks, make you look decades older, in a very realistic and convincing way. “That’s an example of generation,” says Clark, “whether it’s creating art or writing sentences or creating visualizations — this idea that the machines can begin to do some kind of creation. And, as a designer, that’s something that I’m interested in. And I’m actually already seeing machines taking over some of the more rote production oriented aspects of my work.” An example of AI-enabled generation for design can be found in Uizard, an application that enables designers to take a picture of their sketch and then generate a full design in HTML, mapping the familiar symbols of wireframes into complete design patterns.

Clustering and generation begin to feel more like actual intelligence, where the AI is not just improving things we are familiar with in convenient ways, but providing an extra layer of processing beyond what a designer could have imagined before.

What machine learning is perhaps best at is detecting patterns. In this context, Clark proposes that four functions become possible — asking better questions and getting better answers, asking completely different types of questions, accessing new kinds of data, and surfacing invisible patterns.

With AI, we can get better at answering questions and doing it in a more efficient and informed way. For example, rather than brute force matches of a search phrase, AI can enable the creation of semantic vectors around concepts. Further, AI can enable us to ask entirely new kinds of questions. “Instead of searching just for text or for concepts, we are able to search for emotion now,” says Clark. “Imagine somebody at a call center, for example. Instead of receiving things in chronological order … you can actually now look for urgent e-mails, [in which] the phrasing is urgent or angry or upset.” In this example, the AI’s ability to understand and categorize content enables the operator to control their daily workload, proactively directing incoming traffic and workflow around a variety of categories.

Because machines are now able to understand all of the messy ways in which people communicate with each other — what we’re taking pictures of, what our speech is, and what our handwriting says — AI enables us to access new kinds of data. “All of these things that used to be completely opaque to the machines are now machine readable and understandable,” says Clark. “That means that we can mine that for data and for insight, but it also means that we can use those new sources of data as platforms of interaction.”

AI enables us to surface invisible patterns. “The machines are able to see things that we simply can’t, in part because they’re able to go through and make sense of such a vast amount of data and find patterns that were otherwise lost … and we weren’t able to spot ourselves,” says Clark. “It turns out that in many cases, the machines are actually pretty terrible at some of the things that we most care about as human beings,” says Clark. “But they’re great at the things that we often don’t like to do, the things that are repetitive or error prone or joyless tasks. They’re really good at spotting patterns that we don’t spot well. So, I think part of the work of design is to figure out the point in a user journey where the machines can actually be helpful and showing insight that we would not have spotted.”

Clark describes how this human-machine collaboration can ideally work. “I was working with a healthcare company that was trying to figure out how to use machine learning to help radiologists do their job better. Radiologists look at images and X-rays to identify problems in our bodies — masses or other problems. And, much of their work is actually spent looking at things where there are no problems,” says Clark. “It’s this huge amount of work and volume of looking at image after image after image, until they have something that actually does engage their expertise. So, one of the things, for example, that machine learning can do is triage, obviously with a very high degree of sensitivity. We don’t want to have any false negatives where the machines pass on something that is there that is important. The idea is that the machines can do a pass and bring the interesting cases to the humans — not do the humans’ work, but let the humans do what they do best.’ And that is the real opportunity for designers, not just to automate, but to extrapolate what is possible thanks to those new opportunities and even to reimagine larger aspects of the overall system

Clark has significant concerns about data, the raw material that powers so much of machine learning. “I think that we have to be conscious, not just of how we use data, but how as designers we can educate people to be smarter about data, to understand how it’s being used and to what end,” says Clark. “And I think that it’s incumbent on us to be really transparent about how we’re using data. And, I don’t mean that we should put it into the Terms of Use that you have to read thousands and thousands of words of information to be able to use a service.”

“There are a lot of times when people and companies say, ‘Well, you know, if we tell people what we’re doing with their data, they’re not going to want to use our service,’ says Clark. “And I think that should be a huge red flag that if you are saying that, then you probably shouldn’t be doing that thing.”

“You’ve seen in the last couple of years how things can go wrong, how bias can creep into systems in unpleasant ways, how these systems can be used in cynical ways by foreign governments to manipulate democracy by corporations, to take advantage of people who believe that they’re customers who are actually being served by the company, when in fact they are serving the company.”

“The risk of this, for all of the power and promise of machine learning, is that it will quickly reinforce inequalities and magnify gaps, because the people who are using the technology are the ones who will be able to get the most … benefit from it. And then it gets into this very vicious and worrying cycle,” says Clark.

“I choose to be optimistic. I see that these are powerful tools that can be used for good and for bad. And, I think that that’s all the more reason why we need designers and people who really, care about the human experience to be involved in these things, so that they don’t just serve more cynical powers. I think that this is a time when all of us have to choose to be optimistic and to lean into that and, and to bring appropriate skepticism and awareness of how things could go wrong, but also to bring a sense of possibility to these really kind of powerful and exciting new tools.”

Creative Next is a podcast exploring the impact of AI-driven automation on the lives of creative workers, people like writers, researchers, artists, designers, engineers, and entrepreneurs. This article accompanies Season 3, Episode 2 — AI As Design Material.
